2.4.1.title: Overview
2.4.1.content:
The Wait & Weight (Engineer's) Method is a single-circulation kill:

**Concept:**
Kill weight mud is pumped from the start, killing the well in one complete circulation.

**Advantages:**
- Only one circulation required
- Lower maximum casing pressure (shoe pressure)
- Less time under pressure
- More efficient overall

**Disadvantages:**
- Must wait for kill mud preparation
- More complex during first phase (changing DP pressure)
- Requires accurate pressure schedule

**When to Use:**
- Kill mud can be prepared in reasonable time
- Shoe pressure is a concern (tight margin)
- When preferred by operator procedures

2.4.2.title: Pre-Circulation Preparation
2.4.2.content:
Before beginning circulation:

**Kill Mud Preparation:**
- Calculate KWM = Current MW + (SIDPP ÷ 0.052 ÷ TVD)
- Prepare sufficient volume (well volume + reserve)
- Verify weight with accurate measurement
- Mix thoroughly - consistent weight critical

**Kill Sheet:**
- ICP = SCR + SIDPP
- FCP = SCR × (KWM ÷ Current MW)
- Drillpipe pressure schedule (ICP to FCP over strokes to bit)
- Calculate strokes to bit and total circulation strokes

**Verify:**
- Stable SIDPP and SICP
- MAASP will not be exceeded
- Equipment ready
- Crew briefed

**While Waiting:**
- Monitor pressures for gas migration
- May need volumetric method if migration significant
- Keep waiting time reasonable

2.4.3.title: Starting Circulation
2.4.3.content:
**Bringing Pump Up to Speed:**
1. Open choke slightly
2. Start pump slowly
3. As pump speed increases, adjust choke to maintain constant SIDPP
4. Continue increasing speed until at kill rate
5. At kill rate: DP pressure should equal ICP

**Critical Point:**
During startup, maintain SIDPP constant. Once at kill rate and stabilized, ICP is the reference.

**Begin Pumping Kill Mud:**
- Once at ICP and stable, switch suction to kill mud
- Note stroke count when kill mud enters string
- Begin following pressure schedule

2.4.4.title: Drillpipe Pressure Schedule
2.4.4.content:
The key to Wait & Weight is following the pressure schedule:

**Schedule Concept:**
- As kill mud fills drillstring, it adds hydrostatic pressure
- DP pressure must decrease correspondingly
- Linear decrease from ICP to FCP over strokes to bit

**Creating Schedule:**
Calculate DP pressure at regular intervals (e.g., every 100 strokes):
- Pressure drop per stroke = (ICP - FCP) ÷ Strokes to bit
- At stroke X: DP Pressure = ICP - (X × pressure drop per stroke)

**Example Schedule:**
| Strokes | DP Pressure |
|---------|-------------|
| 0       | ICP         |
| 100     | ICP - 10    |
| 200     | ICP - 20    |
| ...     | ...         |
| At bit  | FCP         |

**Following Schedule:**
- Choke operator adjusts to match schedule
- Record actual vs scheduled
- Small deviations acceptable; large deviations indicate problems

2.4.5.title: Kill Mud to Bit Phase
2.4.5.content:
From start until kill mud reaches the bit:

**Drillpipe Pressure:**
- Follows decreasing schedule
- Choke operator adjusts to maintain schedule
- At any point: scheduled pressure = required DP pressure

**Casing Pressure:**
- Initially increases as gas expands
- May fluctuate as influx moves
- NOT the control parameter during this phase
- Monitor for MAASP approach

**Monitor:**
- Compare actual DP pressure to schedule
- Pit volumes
- Pump performance
- Gas at surface indicators

**When Kill Mud Reaches Bit:**
- DP pressure should equal FCP
- Note the stroke count
- Transition to next phase

2.4.6.title: Kill Mud Up Annulus Phase
2.4.6.content:
Once kill mud is at the bit:

**Drillpipe Pressure:**
- Now constant at FCP
- Choke operator maintains FCP
- This is now the control pressure

**Casing Pressure:**
- Should steadily decrease as kill mud rises
- Gas may cause fluctuations as it passes through choke
- Approaches zero as kill mud fills annulus

**Monitoring:**
- Maintain constant FCP
- Watch casing pressure trend (should decrease)
- Monitor pit volumes
- Watch for lost circulation signs

**Gas at Surface:**
- Handle through degasser/separator
- Maintain FCP through fluctuations
- Do not chase casing pressure variations

2.4.7.title: Completing the Kill
2.4.7.content:
When kill mud reaches surface:

**Indicators:**
- Total strokes complete
- Kill mud in returns
- Casing pressure at or near zero
- DP pressure at FCP

**Final Steps:**
1. Stop pumps
2. Close choke
3. Observe pressures (5-10 minute minimum)
4. SIDPP and SICP should both be zero

**If Zero Pressure:**
- Well is killed
- Open choke, flow check
- No flow = well secure
- Document and debrief

**If Residual Pressure:**
- May indicate incomplete kill
- Options: circulate again, increase MW
- Investigate before proceeding

2.4.8.title: Complications
2.4.8.content:
**Pump Problems:**
- If pump fails mid-circulation: shut in, record pressures
- When pump restored: restart using current values
- May need to recalculate schedule

**Lost Circulation:**
- Casing pressure dropping faster than expected
- Pit volume decreasing
- May need to reduce pump rate or mud weight
- Serious complication - see Section 2.11

**Plugged Bit/String:**
- Increasing DP pressure above schedule
- No flow at returns
- May need to work pipe (carefully)
- Serious complication - see Section 2.10

**Gas Migration:**
- If delay occurs mid-circulation with gas in annulus
- Pressures will increase
- May need volumetric method or lubricate and bleed

**Insufficient Kill Mud:**
- Always prepare excess volume
- If supply exhausted: shut in, prepare more, resume
- Do not switch to lighter mud during kill
